newsitem.title: USA: Ex-Miami commissioner Dawkins jailed for 27 months.
newsitem.headline: Ex-Miami commissioner Dawkins jailed for 27 months.

text.p: Former Miami Commissioner Miller Dawkins was sentenced Friday to 27 months jail on federal bribery and conspiracy charges -- part of a corruption scandal that reached the top levels of the city's management.

U.S. District Judge Norman Roettger ordered Dawkins to serve two years supervised release on top of the 27 months behind bars. He must also repay the balance of $20,000 of the $30,000 he received in bribes.
Dawkins told the judge he was sorry for his actions and asked for forgiveness.
Roettger ordered him to begin the sentence on June 3, allowing him to seek treatment for an eye problem. Dawkins will remain free on bond until then.
Dawkins, 71, could have faced up to 15 years in prison and fines of up to $500,000 under a plea agreement, though sentencing guidelines called for no more than 30 months.
He pleaded guilty last October to charges that he took $100,000 in bribes that were purportedly from a computer company, and conspired to accept $100,000 more.

Dawkins admitted he conspired with former city finance director Manohar Surana to solicit kickbacks from Unisys Corp, which was negotiating a $20 million computer contract with the city in March 1995.
Unisys reported the kickback demand to the FBI and helped investigators set up a sting that resulted in Dawkins' arrest.
Surana, who has agreed to plead guilty to unspecified charges, began cooperating with the FBI in March and recorded conversations implicating Dawkins.
Dawkins was also videotaped as he acepted one payment, a paper bag containing $25,000 in cash, in the parking lot of a Denny's restaurant.
He voted twice to approve the Unisys contract, which was unanimously approved by the city commission. Because of his conviction, Dawkins is barred from further elected office.
Law enforcers' "Operation Greenspan" against city hall corruption also led to the downfall of former city manager Cesar Odio, who denies corruption and bribery charges and will fight them in court.
In the wake of the scandal it emerged that the City of Miami had a budget deficit of $68 million and it has been placed under the watch of a state-appointed oversight board.

Dawkin's disgrace also robbed Miami's black population of its traditional seat on the city commission. A Cuban American, Humberto Hernandez, won the the election for his seat, leaving blacks without a voice on the commission for the first time in three decades.
